cards.front: What is a matrix?
cards.back: A rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns.

cards.front: What are the dimensions of a matrix?
cards.back: Number of rows × number of columns.

cards.front: What is a square matrix?
cards.back: A matrix with the same number of rows and columns.

cards.front: What is an identity matrix?
cards.back: A square matrix with 1’s on the main diagonal and 0’s elsewhere, denoted I.

cards.front: How do you add or subtract matrices?
cards.back: Add/subtract corresponding entries. Matrices must have the same dimensions.

cards.front: How do you multiply a matrix by a scalar?
cards.back: Multiply every entry in the matrix by that scalar.

cards.front: When can two matrices be multiplied?
cards.back: If A is m×n and B is n×p, then AB exists and is m×p.

cards.front: How do you multiply matrices?
cards.back: Entry (i,j) of AB = dot product of row i of A and column j of B.

cards.front: Is matrix multiplication commutative?
cards.back: No, in general AB ≠ BA.

cards.front: What is the determinant of a 2×2 matrix [[a, b], [c, d]]?
cards.back: ad − bc

cards.front: What does a zero determinant indicate about a matrix?
cards.back: The matrix is singular (not invertible).

cards.front: What is the inverse of a matrix A?
cards.back: A⁻¹ such that A·A⁻¹ = A⁻¹·A = I.

How can you solve a system AX = B using matrices?
cards.back: If A is invertible, X = A⁻¹B.

cards.front: What is an augmented matrix?
cards.back: A matrix representing a system of equations, with a vertical bar separating coefficients from constants.

cards.front: What is Gaussian elimination?
cards.back: Using row operations to transform an augmented matrix into row-echelon form to solve a system.

cards.front: What are the elementary row operations?
cards.back: 1) Swap two rows. 2) Multiply a row by a nonzero scalar. 3) Add a multiple of one row to another.

cards.front: What is row-echelon form (REF)?
cards.back: All nonzero rows above zero rows; each leading entry is to the right of the one above.

cards.front: What is reduced row-echelon form (RREF)?
cards.back: REF plus each leading entry is 1 and is the only nonzero in its column.

cards.front: What is Cramer’s Rule?
cards.back: A method to solve a linear system using determinants.

cards.front: What is a linear programming problem?
cards.back: Optimizing a linear objective function subject to linear inequality constraints.

cards.front: What are constraints?
cards.back: The linear inequalities that define the feasible region.

cards.front: What is the feasible region?
cards.back: The set of all points satisfying all constraints, usually a convex polygon.

cards.front: What is the objective function?
cards.back: The linear function to be maximized or minimized.

cards.front: What is the corner-point principle?
cards.back: The optimal value occurs at a vertex (corner point) of the feasible region.

cards.front: How do you solve a linear programming problem graphically?
cards.back: 1) Graph constraints. 2) Find feasible region vertices. 3) Evaluate objective at each vertex. 4) Choose optimal.

cards.front: What is a bounded feasible region?
cards.back: A region enclosed on all sides.

cards.front: What is an unbounded feasible region?
cards.back: A region extending infinitely in at least one direction.

cards.front: What is slack in linear programming?
cards.back: The amount of unused resource in a ≤ constraint at the optimal point.

cards.front: What is a standard maximization problem?
cards.back: Maximize a linear function subject to constraints of the form (linear expression) ≤ (non-negative constant), with variables ≥ 0.

cards.front: What is the simplex method?
cards.back: An algebraic algorithm for solving linear programming problems by moving from vertex to vertex.

cards.front: What is a matrix transpose?
cards.back: Swapping rows with columns; Aᵀ has entry (i,j) equal to entry (j,i) of A.

cards.front: What is a symmetric matrix?
cards.back: A square matrix equal to its transpose: A = Aᵀ.

cards.front: What is a scalar matrix?
cards.back: A diagonal matrix where all diagonal entries are equal.

cards.front: What is the trace of a matrix?
cards.back: The sum of the entries on its main diagonal.

cards.front: What is a singular matrix?
cards.back: A square matrix with zero determinant; it has no inverse.

cards.front: What is a nonsingular (invertible) matrix?
cards.back: A square matrix with nonzero determinant; it has an inverse.

cards.front: How do you find the determinant of a 3×3 matrix?
cards.back: Use the rule of Sarrus or cofactor expansion.

cards.front: What is a system’s solution using an inverse matrix?
cards.back: For AX = B, if A is invertible, X = A⁻¹B.

cards.front: Can all linear programming problems be solved graphically?
cards.back: Only those with two variables; three or more variables require algebraic methods like simplex.

cards.front: What is duality in linear programming?
cards.back: Every LP problem (primal) has a related dual problem; solving one gives information about the other.
